item.title: Trump to sit with CBS News in first interview after lawsuit
item.description: The US president is set to sit down with CBS anchor Norah O’Donnell on Friday afternoon, Semafor has learned.

item.title: The new Vanity Fair’s one rule: Leave the princesses alone!
item.description: Vanity Fair is trying to offer meaningful journalism that reveals inner workings of power — while also convincing the powerful to pose for its covers and attend its Hollywood events.

item.title: Can anyone stop Tucker Carlson?
item.description: The uproar over his interview with Nick Fuentes only seemed to boost his profile.

item.title: Wikipedia founder says ‘Gaza genocide’ page lacked neutrality
item.description: The publicly editable nature of Wikipedia makes it a battleground, with entires often becoming viewed as established fact.

item.title: Michael Wolff crowdfunds war chest to pursue Melania Trump
item.description: The first lady had threatened Wolff with a defamation case over comments he made on his podcast linking her to Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Condé Nast abruptly fires 4 staffers after HR confrontation
item.description: The firings were an unsubtle message to its employee union that the publisher was taking a harder line in its dealings with employees.

item.title: Zaslav meets with Comcast executives as bidding war ramps up
item.description: Comcast may feel there is still a path forward for a deal.

item.title: Axel Springer’s CEO — and biggest star — is chasing his next deal
item.description: Mathias Döpfner is emerging as a new-school mogul: ubiquitously public, sitting on a pile of cash, and on the hunt for more deals.

item.title: BBC director general quits over Trump reporting
item.description: He resigned over a report suggesting the broadcaster had misleadingly edited a speech by US President Donald Trump.

item.title: Comcast, Paramount, Netflix near bids for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: A frenetic pursuit for the last big chunk of media assets is entering its next stage.

item.title: An unpublished profile raises questions about Epstein — and journalism
item.description: Buried deep in the House Oversight Committee’s recent release of emails from Jeffrey Epstein’s inbox is an 8,684-word profile by the reporter Michael Wolff.

item.title: The old MSNBC relaunches into a new media world
item.description: The network, now called MS NOW, is in the midst of its biggest gamble since it launched in 1996.

item.title: Vox to partner with Patreon for new paywalled shows
item.description: Vox said it hopes to supplement its shows with live newsroom conversations and community features such as chats.

item.title: Derek Thompson on why everything is becoming television, and whether democracy can survive it
item.description: Derek Thompson explores why endless video feeds are commanding attention like never before, his book Abundance, his shift from The Atlantic, and the leap to independent work.

item.title: Can the Supreme Court keep its secrets? With Jodi Kantor of the New York Times
item.description: New York Times investigative reporter Jodi Kantor joins Mixed Signals to explain how she’s revealed the secrets of internal deliberations behind the ceremony and black robes of the US Supreme Court.

item.title: CNN drops out of Apple News feed, for now
item.description: The two companies are continuing to discuss a new deal that would restore CNN’s stories to Apple News.

item.title: How Trump is trying to remake American culture — starting with his favorite buddy-cop franchise
item.description: The president is offering some creative input on potential upcoming projects.

item.title: UK’s The Telegraph to be taken over by rival Daily Mail
item.description: The outlet has been for sale since its previous owners ran up unsupportable debts and were removed in 2023.
